ï»¿Execution Version Dated 2, 2015 COLLABORATION ARRANGEMENT relating to Global I ifrastructure Facility Partnership Program
ï»¿Execution Version This Collaboration Arrangement is er tered into on 4 , 2015 between: (1) AUSTRALIA AND NEW ZEALAND BANKING GROUP LIMITED, headquartered at 833 1))l is Street, Docklands VIC 3008, Australia, ("ANZ"); and (2) THE WORLD BANK GROUP, comprising the INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTION AND DEVELOPMENT ("IBRD") and INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPI i1i , ASSOCIATION ("IDA"), heacquartered at 1818 H Street, NW, Washington, DC 20433, UU . he INTERNATIONAL FINANCE CORPORATION, ("IFC") headquartered at 2121 Pennsylvai ii Avenue, NW, Washington, D! 20433, USA, and the MULTILATERAL INVESTMENT GUARANTEE AGENCY, ("V IGA"), headquartered at 1818 H Street, NW, Washington, D(: 20433, USA (the "World Bar k Group") (each a "Party" and together the "Parties"). Preamble (A) There is broad internationa recognition, as confirmed by the G20, the OECD, Intel -1 )nal Organizations (IOs), the G77, and the private sector represented by the B20 that investir gD i the infrastructure of Emerging Narkets and Developing Economies (EMDEs) is needed, to Ex: and access to basic services and raise living standards for all, and to meet global economic jr wth targets. (B) Meeting this need presents a significant financing challenge. Given constraints on existing :;:. ces of infrastructure finance-paticularly in the public sector-a redoubled and coordinated e if. -t is needed to mobilize private s(ctor finance for EMDE infrastructure. (C) There is an absence of robust pipelines of structurally sound and bankable projects an :1I s is understood to be the greatest barrier to achieving significantly more infrastructure investrr :d (D) Governments, development inance institutions, donors, and private investors share an in E n. it in developing the market for pri 'ate infrastructure finance in EMDEs: both on the demand sic a ii the numbers of structurally sounJ and bankable projects seeking finance, and gradual emer( En: e of EMDE infrastructure as a recognized asset class; and the supply side, in the range o :i /ate investors that actively particir ate in financing those projects. Achieving these goals will ben : it rom collective action between this range of entities-to leverage resources and knowledge :c find solutions to complex infrastiucture financing challenges that no single institution could ;a:: eve alone. (E) In support of these goals, the Parties propose the establishment of a Global Infrastructure : ility Partnership Program ("GIF", The GIF will be an open global platform aiming at levera;Ii,i the efforts of the wide range of iistitutions currently engaged in supporting EMDE infrastruci.j E Nith the participation of private infrastructure investors, coalescing around project pre; E n: ion, structuring, and risk mitigatio i for individual infrastructure investments. In this regard, the C1- ims to complement existing and proposed services and initiatives currently supported by the :; ties and other prospective GIF partners. The GIF intends to provide resources to prepEro vell- structured, infrastructure pr(jects, and to serve as an additional mechanism for acces :i the expertise of the Parties and other GIF partners, in combination with guidance from pro ie tive private sector financiers into project structures. The GIF thereby aims to achieve greater I e w age of official resources in the ftice of substantial EMDE infrastructure needs-in particular c irge and complex projects with th B potential to attract significant private capital. (F) The Parties are now intere.ted in collaborating in developing the Global Infrastructure :ility Partnership Program, togeth 3r with other partners. 2
ï»¿Execution Version Accordingly, the Parties have com to the following understanding: 1 Global Infrastructure Facili!y Partnership Program Framework 1.1 The GIF is intended 'o be based on the preliminary objectives and principles set c .i Annex 1 (Preliminary GIF Fo. indational Principles). The Parties acknowledge their mutual understanding that while the 31F Foundational Principles are an initial basis for their collaboration, they are of an i idicative nature and will continue to be developed amongst t io Parties and with other potent al partners until the GIF is formally established. The final ver :r of these objectives and principlks will be agreed upon by the GIF Partners and be reflected ii h agreement establishing the C IF. 1.2 The Parties intend to work together with any additional participants who may be collaborating on the GIF to fu-ther enhance their coordination, in particular by developing t -i lF, with a view to formally establ shing the program by June 2015. 2 Further Collaboration 2.1 Pursuant to the foreg oing, the Parties will use reasonable endeavors to continue t, collaborate in developing the GIF, including but not limited to: a. Nature and scope of :ollaboration under the GIF, such as proposed categories of partnership and the r les, rights, and responsibilities associated with each categoi t b. Governance arrange nents of the GIF; c. Operational policies applicable to the GIF's operations; d. Scope of GIF activitiEs and sources/uses of GIF funds, including approach to proje ct selection criteria and coordination with the Parties' existing facilities; and e. Any other aspects of -ollaboration required to finalize the design of the GIF, incluc r g sharing best practice and experience with regard to project preparation, through tl e L e of knowledge platforris for the infrastructure sector. 2.2 During the process of finaliziig the design of the GIF, the multilateral development banks !tI . in Annex 2 will be invited to par:icipate as initial Technical Partners. Once the GIF design is fi i il. ed, additional collaborative effoits are required to develop the operational details for the GI 1 all times complementing existirg efforts and facilities and building upon the shared knowle(ce ind experience of the Parties in this area. This includes determining the level of coordination ta v, en the Parties and project origiration process. 3 General 3.1 This Collaboration Ar angement is not a legally binding agreement or commitment b ") le Parties to enter into or provido support for any specific activity or project. The Parties acknowledge that the provisic ns of this Collaboration Arrangement represent their commoi understanding and intentions only and that the Parties do not intend to create or impose as I gal obligations or liabilities on an Party. 3.2 This Collaboration Ar angement is valid and effective for a period of one year from t 1c date thereof, unless superseced at an earlier date by the establishment of the GIF. 3.3 The Parties expect that this document and information with respect to the collabor it v: activities contemplated hereir will be publicly disclosed. Such disclosure will be made in accordance with the Parties' iespective disclosure policies. The Parties plan to consult witl , :h 3
ï»¿Execution Version other concerning the manner and form of any acknowledgment of the other Party's suppoi regarding the activities. 3.4 Nothing in this arran(iement will constitute or be construed as a waiver, renunciati it other modification of any of the privileges, immunities and exemptions granted to any of th : Parties under their constituert documents, international conventions and any applicable la NS In witness whereof, each of the Par ies has caused this Collaboration Arrangement to be execute c i two (2) counterparts of equal content and form by a duly authorized representative of each Party a; sol the date first set forth above. 4

ï»¿Execution Version THE WORLD BANK GROUP, compr sing the INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTIO I A 4D DEVELOPMENT, the INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT ASSOCIATION, the INTERNATIONAL FINANCE CORPORATION and the MULTILATERAL INVESTMENT GUARANTEE AGENCY 1A By: Bertrand Badre Managing Director and WBG CI7 Financial Officer 6
ï»¿Execution Version Annex I Prelirinary GIF Foundational Principles 1 Objectives 1.1 The objective of the GIF is to promote private sector investment in infrastructure pc je ;ts in emerging markets and developing economies (EMDEs) through robust project preparati :, provision of appropriate risk mitigation instruments, and thereby increasing the commercia ;n I institutional investor engagement in the EMDE infrastructure market. It is focused on collaboration in complex publ!c-private partnerships and projects with potential for commei::a viability which require project preparation resources, policy dialogue and eventual infrastru u financing solutions that no sir gle institution could achieve alone. 1.2 To this end, the GIF iims to create a global platform to provide financial and coort na on resources in collaboration witi the project preparation, advisory, and financing efforts of th M Je range of donor and developrr ent finance institutions currently engaged in supporting EMD:: infrastructure, with the input Eind ideas of private infrastructure investors. GIF's engageme it c. uld stretch from upstream suppoit on project definition, preparation, and investment feasibility assessment, through to dowrstream transaction preparation, financial structuring, and risk mitigation/credit enhancemert. 1.3 Over the longer term by contributing to the stock of high quality and well-structure:1 infrastructure projects, the GI can be expected to help in the development of EMDE infrastructure as an asset cla :s attractive to a wide range of private investors seeking long t: i i assets in faster growing economies, but which until now have been presented only limited infrastructure investment oppDrtunities that meet their risk tolerance and investment profilE;3 2 Operating Principles 2.1 The GIF intends to operate according to the following core principles, to be finalizE L )on agreement among GIF partners: (i) Leveraging the arivate sector-specializing in project financing modalities tl EI ill draw together co nparative advantages of public and private sectors; (ii) Addressing public goods-focusing on core infrastructure; particularly thosE infrastructure prclects that are climate friendly or trade enabling; (iii) Promoting sustainability and inclusiveness-ensuring projects adhere to ti :J practice standarcs for social and environmental responsibility; and (iv) Collaborating, complementing and partnering for solutions-mobilizing tE cl cal and financial resources of all partner entities-World Bank Group entities, mul ilil: ral development institutions, other public institutions, and private investors-in an innovative and flexible way, to complement existing capacities, achieve greatEr leverage and adcress the complex infrastructure financing challenges that are beyond the resoL rces of any individual partner. 3 Institutional Arrangements and Governance 3.1 The GIF is expected :o involve a wide range of stakeholders who are involved in ti hE development and implementation of infrastructure projects, both public and private. GIF p rin. 's are expected to fall into one cr more of the following categories: 7
ï»¿Execution Version (i) Funding Partne s-Partners that provide financial contributions to the GIF w I be considered Fund ng Partners. (ii) Technical Partners-Partners that can and who will agree to provide specific technical advice and support to GIF activities including execution of GIF-fundE d activities and/or provision of GIF-backed credit enhancement or liquidity supp r: instruments. (iii) Advisory Partnurs-Private investors or entities that represent the voice of commercial and/ r institutional investment, whether pension funds, insurance companies, sovereign wealth funds, banks or other financial institutions, as wI! a other multilateral or bilateral agencies engaged in supporting private sector infrastructure prcjects, to be invited into discussions related to project prepara :r optimal approact es to financial structuring, and the design and use of risk instruments, wit a view to ensure suitability of projects for commercial ard/or institutional inve, tment. 3.2 A GIF Governing Council is proposed to oversee the GIF's strategic programmir g management and use of func s, and development of operational policies and procedures; rc hold the GIF Management Unit (see section 4.1) accountable for delivering on the facility', objectives and principles, witi advice and support from the Advisory Partners. The compo ii i of the Governing Council will bE agreed between IBRD and prospective partners, but is prop :)e to comprise representatives of Funding and Technical Partners. 3.3 An Advisory Council comprised of all GIF partners, chaired by the Managing Dir ict and Chief Financial Officer o the World Bank Group, will be periodically convened to facili:E : coordination of GIF activities and support GIF operations. This Advisory Council will serve Esi sounding board, providing g idance and support for GIF Management, and in particular w t I view to ensuring suitability of projects for private sector investment. 4 Management 4.1 The GIF will be administered by the World Bank Group, through a small, dedicate:1 IE im established for this purpose (the GIF Management Unit). The GIF Management Unit will ft r: cn as a coordinating body as projects are identified for inclusion in the pipeline, and then mo' e toward technical support anc financing phases. The GIF Management Unit will not lead in :i'i ual projects. 4.2 GIF activity implemetation teams will be led by selected staff of Technical PartnEr institutions, coordinated by th e GIF Management Unit in consultation with client governmE n:s according to specific project equirements and the project origination processes. Compos t o of the implementation teams m ay vary according to the need of individual projects and governments. 5 Activities and Projects 5.1 Project selection ci iteria and processes could be developed to reflect the follo'.' n principles: (i) Development Irlipact-projects that support the development goals of the G I- partner institutio is; (ii) Alignment-prclects that are aligned with recipient/sponsor country priorities E in strategies; (iii) Complexity-pi ojects that require multiple parties to come together to provid : structuring, arranging and financial support, and/or projects which require a b ei of financial instruments; and 8
ï»¿Execution Version (iv) Catalytic impac :-projects that have significant potential to achieve financial viability, leverage public funds, and attract private sector and/or institutional investors-such as through Public-Private Partnership (PPP) modalities--whi t s 11 meeting governrnent's service delivery objectives. The GIF will focus on infrastr,icture investments that have global public good characteristi l: uch as climate friendly-project:; that are low emitting or encourage efficiency in the provisioi :)l infrastructure services; and trade enabling-projects that facilitate or enhance interconne:: i\ y and trade. 5.2 The scope of suppcrt provided to a particular project will be defined flexibly, with Z aw to complementing the resour;es and support already available from partner entities and o n: funding mechanisms. During the GIF pilot phase, this support may include the following ac tle es, corresponding to major proje.,t development stages: (i) Project definition and enabling environment - sector planning and investment prioritization; pro ect definition, including needs analysis and pre-feasibility sci : ri ng; and legal, regula:ory, or institutional reforms; (ii) Project preparati!n and investment feasibility - feasibility studies, investment appraisal, and P 'P structuring; (iii) Transaction support and financial structuring - preparing and implementing transactions, anc design of risk mitigation/credit enhancement packages; and (iv) Financial arrangiig and credit enhancement - arranging and mobilizing financ 1:3 packages from a range of sources and partners. 6 Operational Policies Sound operational policies- ncluding in particular the management of environmental and s:: al impacts and risks, and transparency in procurement-are critical to the success of infrastr i:t e projects in supporting sustair able, inclusive development; as well as for investors in those projects to manage financial, reputational and legal risks. In developing the appropriate framework for GIF-supported operations, the GIF could draw upon existing arrangements c r external implementing entitie:; under World Bank Partnership Programs. GIF partners will collaborate to establish an approach to fiduciary, environmental and social safeguards an :A! er standards and policies, and (evelop, manage and oversee an accreditation process for G 1- Technical Partners who are ( xpected to function as implementing entities for GIF activitie. 9
